awd_titl_txt: VOSS: Innovating Across Cultures in Virtual Organizations
awd_abstract_narration:
Global collaborations in innovation work are increasingly pervasive and require new forms of virtual organizing. Geographically dispersed projects simultaneously enable novel forms of work, while introducing distance and difference that can cause conflict and confusion. Innovation work, focused on creative practices and exploration of complex and little-known decision spaces, is particularly challenging in these settings, since ambiguity and openness are inherent parts of the process.

This research investigates the social and organizational practices that people employ to work effectively in the face of challenges of distance, cultural separation, temporal pressure, and ambiguity. Specifically, we investigate these practices ethnographically, drawing on Peter Galison?s concept of trading zones as a conceptual framework to examine innovation work across cultures. We build upon and extend a prior study of transnational and intercultural design, in which we encountered three areas of activity to which people attended ? cohesion work (maintaining common understandings and a sense of shared purpose), infrastructure work (sustaining the material conditions of mutual action), and pidgin work (creating of shared languages and patterns of communication). This research takes these initial observations as a starting point for an extensive engagement with intercultural innovation in temporary virtual organizations.

Our research provides a clear view of how cross-cultural collaboration and exchange are accomplished in creative work. Studying existing everyday practices gives us a view into how people configure and orient around existing infrastructures, how they establish patterns and practices of interaction and exchange, and how they maintain coherent group identity and purpose ? in short, how virtual organizing is accomplished in the context of social and material contingencies. Our findings will inform the design and deployment of cyberinfrastructure in virtual organizations, especially when cultural considerations are at play.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, Innovating Across Cultures in Virtual Organizations, we took an ethnographic perspective on transnational contexts of design practice in virtual organizations. In so doing, this work provided insight into the flows of global design practices, intercultural innovation work, and technological design and civic engagement. Through our fieldwork on daily work practices on transnational projects at the design studio in India we were able to observe several projects that were executed primarily in India but were international in scope, commission, and audience. Examples of such projects include: the creation of a public knowledge base on user-centered, low-cost urban sanitation funded by a large American foundation; the planning and execution of an Indian design and innovation conference put on by D-Design with an international audience; and a European-commissioned project on hand hygiene design for developing countries; and a "civic hackathon" in which programmers and technologists came together to brainstorm and prototype technical solutions to problems in political life.

 

Through these ethnographic encounters we discovered a series of themes that focused our findings and enabled us to develop rich knowledge about transnational innovation practices, civic engagement, and cultural ideals. Key themes included: "from knowledge to ethos" (concerning design culture in virtual organizations); "enrolling with rich media" (concerning the role of media in achieving consensus and coherence); "making creating enclaves" (concerning the relationship between design practice and other spheres of creative activity for the designers we studied); and "design and citizenship" (concerning the ways in which discourses of design were invoked as a form of civic solutionism).

 

Although our initial focus was on the conduct of transnational design collaborations, the primary emergent theme from our research has been on the ways in which cultures of design and cultures of political engagement come together. In the years since the project began, this has become more of a topic of conversation with the United States, and we believe that our research has lessons for the development of a technologically-grounded form of civic participation. As such, the broader impact of this study is in relating transnational discourses of design and innovation to efforts to engage citizens in new forms of political and technological activism. To the extent that digital media provide an important new platform for civic engagement, our study has identified ways in which technological design is embedded in broader discourses that shape how we imagine civic life being conducted and the roles of citizens as users and activists.

 

Numerous scholarly products have come from this research.

Irani, L. 2013. Designing Citizens in Transnational India. Completed Dissertation. University of California, Irvine.

 

Peer reviewed publications: 

L. Irani (2015). Hackathons and the Making of Entrepreneurial Citizenship. Forthcoming. Science, Technology, and Human Values.

 

L. Irani (2015). The Cultural Work of Microwork. New Media and Society. 17 (5), 720.
